turn.2: National Committee for a Free Germany The National Committee for a Free Germany (, or NKFD) was a German anti-Nazi organization that operated in the Soviet Union during World War II.
turn.4: The rise of the Nazi Party to power in Germany in 1933 led to the outlawing of the Communist Party of Germany (KPD) and persecutions of its members, many of whom fled to the Soviet Union.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: With the German invasion of the Soviet Union in Operation Barbarossa, German prisoners of war began to fall into Soviet hands.
turn.7: What happened to the prisoners of war?
turn.8: Several attempts to establish an anti-Nazi organization from those POWs were made with little success since most of them still believed in the final victory of the Wehrmacht.
turn.10: With the German defeat at the Battle of Stalingrad, the number of German POWs rose and their belief in a victorious Germany was damaged, hence they were more open to the idea of a membership in an anti-Nazi organization.
turn.12: At the beginning of June 1943, Alfred Kunella and Rudolf Herrnstadt began writing a Committee manifesto.
